natural problem: A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_odd :: real
assumes h0 : "p_odd = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "((1 / 2) powr 6) = 1 / 64"
shows  "p_odd powr 6 = 1 / 64"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{64}
 ### Proof
 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p_odd :: real
assumes h0 : "p_odd = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "((1 / 2) powr 6) = 1 / 64"
shows  "p_odd powr 6 = 1 / 64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If the probability of an event occurring is 1/2, what is the probability of the event occurring 6 times in a row? The final answer is 1/64.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Prod>i\<in>{1..6}. (1 / 2 :: real))"
shows  "p = 1 / 64"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{64}
 ### Proof
 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Prod>i\<in>{1..6}. (1 / 2 :: real))"
shows  "p = 1 / 64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the product of the sequence $\frac{1}{2}$ repeated six times. The final answer is $\frac{1}{64}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rolls :: nat
and odd_product_probability :: real
assumes h0 : "rolls = 6"
and h1 : "odd_product_probability = 1 / (2 ^ rolls)"
shows  "odd_product_probability = 1 / 64"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{64}
 ### Proof
 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes rolls :: nat
and odd_product_probability :: real
assumes h0 : "rolls = 6"
and h1 : "odd_product_probability = 1 / (2 ^ rolls)"
shows  "odd_product_probability = 1 / 64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the probability of getting the product of an odd number when rolling a fair 6-sided die six times. The final answer is $\frac{1}{64}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = 1/2"
and h1 : "P ^ 6 = 1/64"
shows  "P ^ 6 = 1/64"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{64}
 ### Proof
 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = 1/2"
and h1 : "P ^ 6 = 1/64"
shows  "P ^ 6 = 1/64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If $P = \frac{1}{2}$, what is the value of $P^6$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{64}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Prod> i \<in> {1..6}. (1 / 6))"
and h1 : "odd (prod (\<lambda> i. i) {1..6})"
shows  "probability = 1 / 64"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{64}
 ### Proof
 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Prod> i \<in> {1..6}. (1 / 6))"
and h1 : "odd (prod (\<lambda> i. i) {1..6})"
shows  "probability = 1 / 64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A die is rolled six times. What is the probability that all six rolls result in an odd number? The final answer is $\frac{1}{64}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. 1/6 * x)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P x \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "sum P {1..6} = 1"
shows  "P 1 * P 3 * P 5 * P 1 * P 3 * P 5 = 1 / 64"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{64}
 ### Proof
 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. 1/6 * x)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P x \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "sum P {1..6} = 1"
shows  "P 1 * P 3 * P 5 * P 1 * P 3 * P 5 = 1 / 64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A probability function $P(x)$ is defined as $P(x) = \frac{1}{6}x$ for values of $x$ between 1 and 6, inclusive. If the sum of the probabilities for all the values in the range is 1, find the value of $P(1) \cdot P(3) \cdot P(5) \cdot P(1) \cdot P(3) \cdot P(5)$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{64}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die_probability :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> die_probability n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "0 \<le> (\<Prod>n=1..6. die_probability (2 * n - 1))"
shows  "(\<Prod>n=1..6. die_probability (2 * n - 1)) = 1 / 64"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{64}
 ### Proof
 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes die_probability :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> die_probability n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "0 \<le> (\<Prod>n=1..6. die_probability (2 * n - 1))"
shows  "(\<Prod>n=1..6. die_probability (2 * n - 1)) = 1 / 64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A fair six-sided die has a probability of $\frac{1}{6}$ for each number from 1 to 6. Find the product of the probabilities of rolling odd numbers (1, 3, 5) on the die. The final answer is $\frac{1}{64}$.

fixes p_odd :: real
assumes h0 : "p_odd = 1 / 2"
shows  "p_odd^6 = 1 / 64"

 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p_odd :: real
assumes h0 : "p_odd = 1 / 2"
shows  "p_odd^6 = 1 / 64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the value of $(\frac{1}{2})^6$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{64}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die_sides rolls :: nat
assumes h0 : "die_sides = 6"
and h1 : "rolls = 6"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. (x mod 2 = 1) ^ rolls) die_sides = 1 / 64"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{64}
 ### Proof
 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes die_sides rolls :: nat
assumes h0 : "die_sides = 6"
and h1 : "rolls = 6"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. (x mod 2 = 1) ^ rolls) die_sides = 1 / 64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Suppose you roll a fair 6-sided die 6 times. What is the probability that all 6 rolls result in an odd number? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{1}{64}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Prod> i = 1..6. (1 / 6) * count {1, 3, 5} i)"
shows  "P = 1 / 64"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard die is rolled six times. What is the probability that the product of all six rolls is odd? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{64}
 ### Proof
 The product of all six rolls is odd if and only if each roll is odd. Any given roll has an odd result with probability $\frac{1}{2}$. The probability of all six rolls being odd is therefore $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = \boxed{\frac{1}{64}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Prod> i = 1..6. (1 / 6) * count {1, 3, 5} i)"
shows  "P = 1 / 64"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the probability of selecting an odd number in a six-sided fair die. Use the formula $P = \prod_{i=1}^6 \frac{1}{6} \times \text{count of odd numbers}$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{64}$.
